data.title: Argentina Economy, Politics and GDP Growth Summary
data.meta_description: Access the latest politics analysis and economic growth summary through 2011 for Argentina from The Economist Intelligence Unit
data.text:
In brief

The president, Javier Milei of the far-right La Libertad Avanza (LLA), is pursuing shock fiscal consolidation measures and market-friendly reforms early in his term. Despite being popular, Mr Milei's legislative agenda has stalled, partly because his party lacks a legislative majority and partly because of opposition from centrist parties and governors. Mr Milei's hostile rhetoric and uncompromising policy views have weakened governability further. The reforms that the new administration has enacted through a mega-decree are facing judicial challenges that threaten to reverse the progress made. On a more positive note, the government is likely to enter a new programme with the IMF this year, which will bolster policy credibility.

Inflationary pressures will remain high in the first half of 2024 following a maxi-devaluation of the peso in December 2023, sharp cuts to subsidies and an end to price controls. Domestic demand will also suffer from the government's front-loaded fiscal consolidation measures. These measures will cause the economy to contract sharply in 2024, although the combination of a reduction in the import bill and a boost to exports from a bumper harvest and rising mining and hydrocarbons output will lead to a current-account surplus and will help make up for some of the overall decline in economic performance.

Looking ahead to 2025, we forecast a robust economic recovery on the back of a more supportive business environment. Moreover, a gradual lifting of currency controls will boost investment, and disinflation will spur a recovery in private consumption. Mr Milei's more radical plans, such as dollarisation and the closure of the central bank, are unlikely to materialise.

Read more: What to watch in 2024: Argentina

Read more: What does Milei's mega-decree mean for Argentina's economy?
